subject: Re: [junit] Re: execute code upon failed test in junit 4
msgSnippet: Another option is to create a TestListener and implement testFailed method which should be invoked when any test fails.
messageBody:
Another option is to create a TestListener and implement testFailed
method which should be invoked when any test fails.

On Mon, Apr 20, 2009 at 3:12 AM, mykro76 <danieljcarr@...> wrote:
>
>
> Thanks David for the tip, I'll see if I can work this into a custom Runner.
> In the meantime, I have logged it as a New Feature in the tracker (ID:
> 2775189)
>
> Regards!
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
>> It's not currently possible in a simple way, but I think I know the
>> right way to build the possibility into 4.7. Feel free to log a
>> feature request to track progress.
>>
>> That said, if you're willing to write a custom Runner class, you could
>> get this behavior.
>>
>> David Saff
>>
>> On Fri, Apr 17, 2009 at 2:02 AM, mykro76 <danieljcarr@...> wrote:
>> > I'm using Junit 4 annotations, @Before, @After, @Test, etc.  I can't
>> > find a way to execute code only when a test fails.   In essence, an @OnFail
>> > annotation.  Is this possible?
>> > The only solutions I've seen posted in this list were for Junit3, or
>> > involved setting a success flag at the end of *every* test.  Neither of
>> > which is very appealing.
>> > Backstory: I created a CacheAppender for log4j which stores large
>> > volumes of DEBUG level logging.  ERROR, WARN, INFO etc continue to go to the
>> > default ConsoleAppender in realtime.  If the test fails, I want to dump the
>> > contents of CacheAppender to the ConsoleAppender.  If the test succeeds I
>> > want to discard this extra logging.   Is there a better way I could be doing
>> > this?
>> > Thanks!
>
>
